introduction.title: Overview
introduction.p:
Sequences are often introduced to us as young children as a tool to look for basic numerical patterns. We are shown the start to a list of numbers and asked if we can identify the next few numbers in the list or are asked to identify the rule being used to generate the sequence.
1, 5, 9, 13, \ldots 2, 6, 18, 54, \ldots
You probably recognized that in the first sequence, the next number would be 17 because the pattern involved adding 4 to the previous number. In the second sequence, you probably saw that we were multiplying by the value 3, so that the next number would have been 162. These patterns help motivate the mathematical definition of a sequence.

We study sequences because they illustrate a number of ideas we will use in calculus. We eventually want to describe functions as dynamic models. Dynamical models for sequences are easier to illustrate than for general functions. We want a clearer definition for limits. Limits for sequences introduce the ideas of approximation that are necessary for limits of functions. Finally, in calculus we will measure the accumulated change of a quantity when we know its rate. Accumulation formulas for sequences will provide the tools we need to define more general accumulations.

This section introduces the basic terminology for sequences. It explains how a sequence is a special type of function, where the domain is a set of integers. We will learn about explicit formulas for a sequence and recursive formulas for a sequence, using arithmetic and geometric sequences as our original motivation.

subsection.title: Basic Terminology
subsection.p: A sequence is an ordered set of numbers. The idea of being ordered is that we can say what the first number is, what the second number is, and so forth. To emphasize that the number have assigned positions, a sequence can be written as an ordered list using parentheses. The entire sequence can be assigned a symbol, just like a variable, so that a sequence assigned a symbol x and given by the values 1, 5, 9, 13, etc., would be written x = (1, 5, 9, 13, \ldots).

Because the sequence has a specific order, we use an index as a way of counting through the sequence. For a given sequence, the term with index 1 is the first number of the sequence, the term with index 2 is the second number, the term with index 3 is the third number, and so forth. We use subscripts on a sequence to refer to an indexed value. So x_1 is the first value of sequence x and x_5 refers to the value of the sequence x with index 5.

statement.p: For the sequence x = (1,5,9,13,\ldots), find each of the following values: x_1, x_3, and x_5.

solution.p:
We can create a mapping between the index (ordering) and the values of the sequence. \begin{matrix} n & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 \\ \downarrow \\ x_n & 1 & 5 & 9 & 13 & 17 & 21 \end{matrix} From this relation, we can identify the values.
x_1 & = 1 x_3 & = 9 x_5 & = 17

subsection.p: Once we recognize that a sequence has an association between an index (the integer counting through the terms) and the values of the sequence, we should be able to recognize that every sequence corresponds to a function. In fact, this leads to the formal definition of a sequence.

statement.p: A sequence x is a function with a domain D that is a subset of integers (usually D=\mathbb{N}=\{1,2,3,\ldots\} or D=\mathbb{N}_0 = \{0,1,2,3,\ldots\}) and values that are real numbers. x : D \to \mathbb{R}, n \mapsto x_n. The value of the sequence is a function of the index.

subsection.p: In the definition of a sequence, the first index value does not need to be 1. Any integer could be the first value in the domain. Also, the variable of the index is not always n. By convention, however, it is most often a letter from the middle of the alphabet. We show that a sequence starts with a particular index value, say n_0, by including the following additional notation: x = (x_n)_{n=n_0}^{\infty}.

statement.p:
The sequence u=(u_k)_{k=-1}^{\infty} = (8, 5, 2, -1, -4, \ldots) follows a simple pattern. The first index value is k=-1. The sequence has the following values:
u_{-1} = 8, u_{0} = 5, u_{1} = 2, u_{2} = -1.

paragraphs.title: Explicit Representations
paragraphs.p:
Because a sequence is a function of the index, we sometimes have explicit definitions for sequence values. A sequence might be defined through a simple formula and the domain, x_n = \frac{n}{n+1}, \quad n \in D=\{1, 2, 3, \ldots\}. The formula acts like a function, but instead of writing x(n), a sequence uses subscript notation. Values of the sequence can be found just like for functions.
x_1 &= x(1) = \frac{1}{1+1} = \frac{1}{2}, x_2 &= x(2) = \frac{2}{2+1} = \frac{2}{3}, x_{10} &= x(10) = \frac{10}{10+1} = \frac{10}{11}.
With this interpretation, we can even do composition to find the sequence value at an index defined by a formula.
x_{n+1} &= x(n+1) = \frac{(n+1)}{(n+1)+1} = \frac{n+1}{n+2}, x_{2n} &= x(2n) = \frac{2n}{2n+1}, x_{n^2} &= x(n^2) = \frac{n^2}{n^2+1}.

statement.p: Find an explicit formula for the sequence x = (\frac{1}{4}, \frac{1}{9}, \frac{1}{16}, \frac{1}{25}, \ldots), and then find x_{12} and x_{2n}.

solution.p: To find the explicit formula, we look for a pattern in the sequence and then try to find a relationship between the index and the pattern. In this case, every sequence value is the reciprocal of a perfect square. If we look at this pattern with a table showing the index and the pattern, we find a relationship.

paragraphs.p: The graph of a sequence corresponds to the points (n, x_n). This graph will be discrete points because the domain only includes integers.

statement.p: Graph the sequence \displaystyle x_n = \frac{n}{n+1}, defined for n=1, 2, 3, \ldots.

solution.p: This is the sequence discussed above. The plot will include the points \{(n, x_n) : x_n=\frac{n}{n+1}, n=1, 2, 3, \ldots\} = \{(1,\frac{1}{2}), (2,\frac{2}{3}), (3,\frac{3}{4}), (4, \frac{4}{5}), \ldots\}.

subsection.title: Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences
subsection.p: For ordinary functions, we usually expect them to be represented using an explicit formula. But we often think of sequences in terms of a pattern for finding a value based on the previous value. Such a representation is called recursive. The simplest sequences follow simple recursive patterns.

An arithmetic sequence is a sequence whose terms change by a fixed increment or difference. For example, consider the first sequence introduced in the section, x = (1, 5, 9, 13, \ldots). The pattern for this sequence was that we add 4 to each term in the sequence to find the next term. The value 4 is called the difference of the sequence.

A geometric sequence is a sequence whose terms change by a fixed multiple or ratio. The second sequence of the section was a geometric sequence, u= (2, 6, 18, 54, \ldots). Each term is found by multiplying the previous term by 3, which is the ratio of the sequence.

For recursively defined sequences, the equation that describes the relationship between consecutive terms of the sequence is called the recurrence relation. When the equation is solved for the new term as a function of the previous term, we have a recursive formula that uses a projection function.

statement.p: Suppose a sequence x is defined by a recurrence relation of the form x_{n+1} = f(x_n). The function f defining the relation x_{n} \mapsto x_{n+1} is called the projection function.

subsection.p: To make sense of recursive formulas, we first need to understand the notation x_{n+1} and x_{n-1}. For a specific value of n, say n=3, we have n+1=4 and n-1=2. Thus for n=3 so that x_n=x_3, we must have x_{n+1} = x_{4} and x_{n-1}=x_2. Just as x_4 is the term after x_3 and x_2 is the term before x_3, the general formula x_{n+1} refers to the term after x_n and x_{n-1} is the term before x_n, speaking of a generic index n. Similarly, x_{n+3} would refer to the value 3 terms after x_n.

statement.p: A sequence is defined by the recurrence relation u_{n+1}-u_n = 1.4 u_n - \frac{3}{u_n}, \quad n \ge -1, and an initial value u_{-1}=1. Find the recursive equation corresponding to the projection function, u_n \mapsto u_{n+1}, and find f(x). Use this to find u_0 and u_1.

solution.p:
As a map, we can repeatedly use this function to find subsequent values of the sequence.
u_{-1} &= 1 u_{0} &= f(u_{-1}) = f(1) &= 2.4(1)-\frac{3}{1} = -0.6 u_{1} &= f(u_0) = f(-0.6) &= 2.4(-0.6)-\frac{3}{-0.6} = 3.56

paragraphs.title: Arithmetic Sequences
paragraphs.p:
Because an arithmetic sequence has a constant difference between terms, the recurrence relation is defined through the difference. Consider our arithmetic sequence above, x=(1,5,9,13,\ldots), which has a constant difference of 4 between terms. That is, all of the following equations are true about our sequence:
x_2 - x_1 &= 5-1 = 4, x_3 - x_2 &= 9-5 = 4, x_4 - x_3 &= 13-9 = 4, & \vdots
This infinite collection of equations is captured as a pattern with a single formula, x_{n+1} - x_n = 4, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots. This equation is a recurrence relation. Alternatively, we could also represent the same pattern with a slightly different recurrence relation, x_{n} - x_{n-1} = 4, \quad n=2, 3, 4, \ldots. The first equation is interpreted as looking forward in the sequence (x_{n+1} is future relative to x_n) while the second equation is interpreted as looking backward (x_{n-1} is prior to x_n).

The recursive formula is defined by solving the recurrence relation in terms of the later term in the sequence. The first equation, solved for x_{n+1}, gives one possible recursive formula, x_{n+1} = x_n + 4, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots. Solving the second equation for x_n gives an equivalent recursive formula x_{n} = x_{n-1} + 4, \quad n=2, 3, 4, \ldots. In either case, the projection function defining the recursive formula is the same, f(x) = x+4.
The same pattern generalizes for every arithmetic sequence.

statement.p: An arithmetic sequence x with domain D=\{1,2,3,\ldots\} and defined with constant difference c has a recurrence relation x_{n+1} - x_n = c and a recursive formula for the next term given by x_{n+1} = x_n + c, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots. The projection function is f(x) = x+c.

paragraphs.p:
Because arithmetic sequences result from repeated addition of the same value, such sequences can be written explicitly as linear functions of the index. Consider a general arithmetic sequence with recursive definition x_{n+1} = x_n + \beta, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots, with initial value x_1=c. Look at the pattern of values for the sequence.
x_1 &= c x_2 &= x_1 + \beta = c+\beta x_3 &= x_2+ \beta = (c+\beta)+\beta = c + 2\beta x_4 &= x_3+ \beta = (c+2\beta)+\beta = c + 3\beta x_5 &= x_4+ \beta = (c+3\beta)+\beta = c + 4\beta
Notice that for a given index n, the term x_n includes (n-1)\beta, so that the explicit formula is given by x_n = \beta(n-1) + c.

An alternative approach to this formula is to recognize that a graph of an arithmetic sequence using points (n, x_n) will be on a line with slope \beta. Further, we know the point from the first index is (n,x_n)=(1,c). The pointslope equation of this line is given by x_n = \beta(n-1)+c.

paragraphs.title: Geometric Sequences
paragraphs.p: A geometric sequence is defined by a constant ratio between terms. The constant ratio is defined with the future term on top and the previous term on bottom. For our example geometric sequence, u=(2,6,18,54,\ldots), our constant ratio is 3: \frac{u_2}{u_1} = \frac{6}{2} = 3, \quad \frac{u_3}{u_2} = \frac{18}{6} = 3, \quad \ldots Generalizing this patterns gives us one possible recurrence relation, \frac{u_{n+1}}{u_n} = 3, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots. Cross-multiplying gives us another possible recurrence formula that is also a recursive definition for our sequence, u_{n+1} = 3 u_n, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots. This corresponds to a projection function f(x) = 3x.

statement.p: A geometric sequence x with domain D=\{1,2,3,\ldots\} and defined with constant ratio \rho has a recurrence relation \displaystyle \frac{x_{n+1}}{x_n} = \rho and a recursive formula for the next term given by x_{n+1} = \rho x_n, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots. The projection function is f(x) = \rho x.

paragraphs.p:
Geometric sequences result from repeated multiplication by the same value. Consider a general geometric sequence with recursive definition x_{n+1} = \alpha \cdot x_n, \quad n=1, 2, 3, \ldots, with initial value x_1=c. Since repeated multiplication corresponds to powers, we can find a pattern that leads to the general explicit formula for the sequence value as a function of the index.
x_1 &= c x_2 &= \alpha x_1 = \alpha c x_3 &= \alpha x_2 = \alpha(\alpha c) = \alpha^2 c x_4 &= \alpha x_3 = \alpha(\alpha^2 c) = \alpha^3 c x_5 &= \alpha x_4 = \alpha(\alpha^3 c) = \alpha^4 c
The power of \alpha is always one smaller than the value of the index. Our general explicit formula for the sequence value as a function of the index is given by x_n = c \cdot \alpha^{n-1}.
These results generalize to being given any particular value in the sequence. We state this as a theorem for later reference.

statement.p: An arithmetic sequence with increment \beta and given value x_k satisfies the explicit formula x_n = x_k + \beta(n-k).
A geometric sequence with ratio \rho and given value x_k satisfies the explicit formula x_n = x_k \cdot \rho^{n-k}.

ul.li: Sequences are functions with domains that are subsets of the integers. The independent variable (input) is called the index and the dependent variable (output) is called the value.
An explicit representation of a sequence x is when there is a function for the mapping n \mapsto x_n. Sequence evaluation, including composition, follow standard function rules.
A recursive representation of a sequence x is when there is a function relating consecutive values x_n \mapsto x_{n+1}. This function is called the projection function.
An arithmetic sequence with common difference c has a projection function f(x)=x+c, a recursive relation x_{n+1}=x_n + c, and an explicit formula given a known value for x_k, x_n = x_k + \beta(n-1).

A geometric sequence with common ratio \rho has a projection function f(x)=\rho x, a recursive relation x_{n+1}=\rho \cdot x_n, and an explicit formula given a known value for x_k, x_n = x_k \cdot \rho^{n-k}.

Find an explicit formula for each of the following sequences.
x = (x_n)_{n=0}^{\infty} = (1, 4, 9, 16, 25, \ldots)
y = (y_n)_{n=1}^{\infty} = (\frac{1}{4}, \frac{2}{9}, \frac{3}{16}, \frac{4}{25}, \ldots)

A sequence is defined explicitly with the formula x_n = -3n+20, \qquad n=0, 1, 2, 3, \ldots.
List the first five values in the sequence.
Compute x_{n+1} and then simplify x_{n+1}-x_n.
Use the previous result to write down a recurrence relation.

A sequence is defined explicitly with the formula y_k = \frac{2^{k-2}}{3^{k}}, \qquad k=0, 1, 2, 3, \ldots.
List the first five values in the sequence.
Compute y_{k+1} and then simplify \displaystyle \frac{y_{k+1}}{y_k}.
Use the previous result to write down a recurrence relation.

A sequence is defined recursively by x_{n+1} = 2x_n - 5, \quad n=0, 1, 2, \ldots, with an initial value x_0=6.
If f : x_n \mapsto x_{n+1} is the projection function, find f(x).
Find x_1, x_2, and x_3.

A sequence is defined recursively by u_{k+1} = \frac{u_k}{2} + \frac{3}{u_k}, \quad k=0, 1, 2, \ldots, with an initial value u_0=6.
If f is the projection function u_k \mapsto u_{k+1}, find f(x).
Find u_1, u_2, and u_3.
